#Text=XIII

#Text=WHEN Violet Melrose had said to Susy Branch , the winter before in New York : “ But why on earth do n’t you and Nick go to my little place at Versailles for the honeymoon ? I ’m off to China , and you could have it to yourselves all summer , ” the offer had been tempting enough to make the lovers waver .

#Text=It was such an artless ingenuous little house , so full of the demoralizing simplicity of great wealth , that it seemed to Susy just the kind of place in which to take the first steps in renunciation .

#Text=But Nick had objected that Paris , at that time of year , would be swarming with acquaintances who would hunt them down at all hours ; and Susy ’s own experience had led her to remark that there was nothing the very rich enjoyed more than taking pot-luck with the very poor .
#Text=They therefore gave Strefford ’s villa the preference , with an inward proviso ( on Susy ’s part ) that Violet ’s house might very conveniently serve their purpose at another season .
#Text=These thoughts were in her mind as she drove up to Mrs. Melrose ’s door on a rainy afternoon late in August , her boxes piled high on the roof of the cab she had taken at the station .

#Text=She had travelled straight through from Venice , stopping in Milan just long enough to pick up a reply to the telegram she had despatched to the perfect housekeeper whose permanent presence enabled Mrs. Melrose to say :
#Text=“ Oh , when I ’m sick of everything I just rush off without warning to my little shanty at Versailles , and live there all alone on scrambled eggs . ”
#Text=The perfect house-keeper had replied to Susy ’s enquiry :

#Text=“ Am sure Mrs. Melrose most happy ” ; and Susy , without further thought , had jumped into a Versailles train , and now stood in the thin rain before the sphinx-guarded threshold of the pavilion .

#Text=The revolving year had brought around the season at which Mrs. Melrose ’s house might be convenient : no visitors were to be feared at Versailles at the end of August , and though Susy ’s reasons for seeking solitude were so remote from those she had once prefigured , they were none the less cogent .
#Text=To be alone -- alone !

#Text=After those first exposed days when , in the persistent presence of Fred Gillow and his satellites , and in the mocking radiance of late summer on the lagoons , she had fumed and turned about in her agony like a trapped animal in a cramping cage , to be alone had seemed the only respite , the one craving : to be alone somewhere in a setting as unlike as possible to the sensual splendours of Venice , under skies as unlike its azure roof .
#Text=If she could have chosen she would have crawled away into a dingy inn in a rainy northern town , where she had never been and no one knew her .
#Text=Failing that unobtainable luxury , here she was on the threshold of an empty house , in a deserted place , under lowering skies .

#Text=She had shaken off Fred Gillow , sulkily departing for his moor ( where she had half-promised to join him in September ) ; the Prince , young Breckenridge , and the few remaining survivors of the Venetian group , had dispersed in the direction of the Engadine or Biarritz ; and now she could at least collect her wits , take stock of herself , and prepare the countenance with which she was to face the next stage in her career .
#Text=Thank God it was raining at Versailles !
#Text=The door opened , she heard voices in the drawing-room , and a slender languishing figure appeared on the threshold .
#Text=“ Darling ! ” Violet Melrose cried in an embrace , drawing her into the dusky perfumed room .
#Text=“ But I thought you were in China ! ”
#Text=Susy stammered .

#Text=“ In China ... in China , ” Mrs. Melrose stared with dreamy eyes , and Susy remembered her drifting disorganised life , a life more planless , more inexplicable than that of any of the other ephemeral beings blown about upon the same winds of pleasure .
#Text=“ Well , Madam , I thought so myself till I got a wire from Mrs. Melrose last evening , ” remarked the perfect house-keeper , following with Susy ’s handbag .
#Text=Mrs. Melrose clutched her cavernous temples in her attenuated hands .
#Text=“ Of course , of course ! I had meant to go to China -- no , India ... .
#Text=But I ’ve discovered a genius ... and Genius , you know ... . ”

#Text=Unable to complete her thought , she sank down upon a pillowy divan , stretched out an arm , cried : “ Fulmer ! Fulmer ! ” and , while Susy Lansing stood in the middle of the room with widening eyes , a man emerged from the more deeply cushioned and scented twilight of some inner apartment , and she saw with surprise Nat Fulmer , the good Nat Fulmer of the New Hampshire bungalow and the ubiquitous progeny , standing before her in lordly ease , his hands in his pockets , a cigarette between his lips , his feet solidly planted in the insidious depths of one of Violet Melrose ’s white leopard skins .
#Text=“ Susy ! ” he shouted with open arms ; and Mrs. Melrose murmured :
#Text=“ You did n’t know , then ?
#Text=You had n’t heard of his masterpieces ? ”
#Text=In spite of herself , Susy burst into a laugh .
#Text=“ Is Nat your genius ? ”
#Text=Mrs. Melrose looked at her reproachfully .
#Text=Fulmer laughed .
#Text=“ No ; I ’m Grace ’s .
#Text=But Mrs. Melrose has been our Providence , and ... . ”
#Text=“ Providence ? ” his hostess interrupted .
#Text=“ Do n’t talk as if you were at a prayer-meeting !
#Text=He had an exhibition in New York ... it was the most fabulous success .
#Text=He ’s come abroad to make studies for the decoration of my music-room in New York .
#Text=Ursula Gillow has given him her garden-house at Roslyn to do .
#Text=And Mrs. Bockheimer ’s ball-room -- oh , Fulmer , where are the cartoons ? ”
#Text=She sprang up , tossed about some fashion-papers heaped on a lacquer table , and sank back exhausted by the effort .
#Text=“ I ’d got as far as Brindisi .
#Text=I ’ve travelled day and night to be here to meet him , ” she declared .
#Text=“ But , you darling , ” and she held out a caressing hand to Susy , “ I ’m forgetting to ask if you ’ve had tea ? ”
